items.title: What are the US federal spending bill talks really about? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A second spending plan has failed to clear the US House of Representatives. The plan was supported by President-elect Donald Trump. But dozens of Republicans joined with Democrats in refusing to back a bill that would also have suspended the debt ceiling. With some Republicans reluctant to fall in line behind Trump, is this a warning sign to him?

#Shutdown #ElonMusk #DonaldTrump

items.title: Car slams into crowd at Christmas market | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A car was driven into a crowd of people at a Christmas market in the central German city of Magdeburg on Friday night. Two people have been killed, according to Saxony-Anhalt's state premier, Reiner Haseloff, who said at least 60 more had been injured, many seriously. Haseloff said police have taken the driver, a Saudi national, into custody and believe he acted alone. Magdeburg police also announced an arrest online.

items.title: Reports: At least 11 dead as car plowed into Christmas market in Germany's Magdeburg | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content: A car was driven into a crowd of people at a Christmas market in the central German city of Magdeburg on Friday night.bAt least two people have been killed, according to Saxony-Anhalt's  state premier, Reiner Haseloff. City spokesperson Michael Reif said there were "numerous injured," with media reports suggesting that number to be around 70.  Police have taken the driver into custody, according to local government sources cited by Germany's dpa news agency. Authorities say the individual, a Saudi national, is not known to have Islamist ties. Authorities have closed the Christmas market and emergency services are at the scene. A spokesperson for Magdeburg University Hospital told dpa that the first 10-20 victims have already arrived at the facility, adding, "We are currently gearing up [for more]. Intensive care beds are ready." No information about the driver of the car been released and despite wild public speculation on social media sites authorities in Magdeburg have avoided any statement on a possible motive. Friday's incident did, nevertheless, trigger memories of a 2016 attack on a Berlin Christmas market. That crime, perpetrated by an Islamist in a stolen truck, killed 13 and injured more than 70.

items.title: Germany: Car drives into crowd at Magdeburg Christmas market | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content: A car drove into a crowd of people at a Christmas market in the central German city of Magdeburg on Friday night. At least one person was killed, according to German media reports. Multiple people were reportedly injured. Police have taken the driver into custody, according to local government sources cited by Germany's dpa news agency. Authorities have closed the Christmas market and emergency services are at the scene.The premier of the state of Saxony-Anhalt, Reiner Haseloff, is on his way to Magdeburg, public broadcaster MDR reported. The broadcaster also cited a spokesman for the state government as describing the incident as an attack. Magdeburg, a city west of Berlin, is the state capital of Saxony-Anhalt and is home to around 240,000 people.

items.title: Traumatized and living in fear: Gaza's children fight for survival | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Doctors in Gaza say at least thirty Palestinians, including children, have been killed in the latest Israeli airstrikes. Mediators are still working to secure a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas. For children in Gaza, a deal can't come soon enough. Most have already lost family, friends and their homes. And with schools closed, they're also losing their education.

items.author: DW News
items.content:

items.title: German payment card for asylum seekers sparks criticism | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Caption: Germany's roll out of a payment card to distribute funds to asylum seekers has been met with criticism. The new system launched this year and was devised to make it harder for cardholders to send money outside of Germany. But detractors of the new program say it also makes spending money on necessities here in Germany more difficult.

items.title: How Ukraine tries to change the battlefield with ground drones | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
As Russia's war against Ukraine approaches its third anniversary, Kyiv has to innovate for its defence. It's emerging as a testing ground for high-tech, cutting-edge drone warfare. Aerial and sea drones have already destroyed much of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet. But on land, drones are still in their infancy.

items.title: China builds a new $3.5bn megaport in Peru: Why is it facing pushback? | Transforming Business
items.author: DW News
items.content:
China’s new $3.5bn megaport in Peru strengthens the trade relationship between the two countries and gives it direct access to Latin America’s valuable minerals, ensuring its own strategic growth and control over the global mineral supply chain. But the megaport has been described as environmentally destructive, at a time when the maritime industry is honing its green efforts.

03:50 Carbon Capture and Green Hydrogen
05:33 On-Shore Power

items.title: Will these former Islamist rebels run Syria as a secular state? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
The first US diplomats to visit Syria since the fall of the Assad regime have arrived in Damascus. They're holding talks with the rebels who now form the de-facto government, and who the US and other states still classify as a terrorist organization. 
It's a sign of transition that's also reflected across the country, where some members of former President Assad's military are being integrated into the new order. They've been told to hand over their weapons or face prosecution. And many say they're happy to do so.

Chapters
00:00 Former Syrian soldiers hand over their weapons
04:25 Mohamad Chreyteh, DW correspondent
08:48 Burcu Ozcelik, Senior Research Fellow for Middle East Security atRoyal United Services Institute

items.title: How Assad’s fall is shaking up Germany’s migration debate | Berlin Briefing podcast
items.author: DW News
items.content:
In this episode, we dive into the complexities surrounding the future of Syrians in Germany. After the Assad regime was toppled, the German government decided to suspend asylum proceedings for Syrian citizens. The debate in Germany has been heating up since then- not least because political parties are attempting to stress their differences even more than usual: We properly entered election campaign period this week, after all, with German chancellor Olaf Scholz losing the requested vote of confidence in parliament, paving the way for elections on February 23rd. Host Nina Haase speaks to DW's Michaela Küfner and migration expert Raphael Bossong from SWP think tank about where Germany stands-almost ten years after Angela Merkel said "we can do this" about taking in more than a million people.

Key discussions include:

The potential impact on the German labor market if a large number of Syrians were to return to Syria
The varying statuses of Syrians in Germany and the implications of these differences
The evolution of German conservatives’ migration policies since Angela Merkel
The role of migration and asylum policies in the current German election campaign

🔔 Subscribe to the DW Berlin Briefing podcast for more insightful analysis on global affairs. We'll have a new episode out every week. If you can't wait that long - do subscribe to our Berlin Briefing newsletter: https://www.dw.com/en/berlinbriefing/... 

#BerlinBriefing #TransatlanticRelations #EuropeanSecurity

items.title: How influential is Musk among the far right in Germany? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Elon Musk, who's also a close adviser to Donald Trump, posted on X that the far-right Alternative for Germany is the only party that can save Germany. The AFD is at odds with the country's mainstream parties, because of its hardline anti-immigrant and anti-European Union stances. It's also under observation by German law enforcement because parts of the party are suspected of seeking to undermine Germany's democratic order.
